Investing your money

For many the idea of investing money is a bit like walking along the ridge of a mountain – it feels precarious, maybe even dangerous. 

At Wellspring Financial we help you understand how investing your money can make it work harder for you over the longer-term. Our team will take time to help you understand the benefits and risks of your investments and design strategies to fit with your goals, budget, and chosen level of risk. 

We focus on building long-term client relationships. Our team will walk alongside you, ensuring you receive regular reports and reviews to help keep your investments on track. So, whether you are saving your surplus income or investing an inheritance; we are here to guide you along the path to a brighter financial future.

Tax-efficient savings

Benjamin Franklin once said, “…in this world, nothing is certain except death and taxes.” 

Whilst we can’t do anything about the former, our team will take account of your tax status and remaining allowances for products such as ISA’s and Pensions, to make investing tax efficient for you. 

Ethical investing

Sometimes our clients want to avoid investing in a particular company or market sector that they find unpleasant or offensive. This ethical approach can also be used positively. For example, investing in companies that work towards improving their local community or whose products and services are environmentally friendly.

Whatever your preferences are, our team is skilled in working with clients to identify funds that match them. 

An ISA is a medium to long term investment, which aims to increase the value of the money you invest for growth or income or both. The value of your investments and any income from them can fall as well as rise. You may not get back the amount you invested.

HM Revenue and Customs practice and the law relating to taxation are complex and subject to individual circumstances and changes which cannot be foreseen.

Tax concession are not guaranteed and may change in the future. Tax free means the investor pays no tax.
